Immunometabolism

Nature Immunology volume 26, page 1839 (2025)Cite this article

Subjects

Cadaverine is a polyamine previously linked to disease owing to alterations in energy metabolism. However, the biological relevance of cadaverine synthesized by gut microbiota is unknown. In Cell Host and Microbe, de Oliveira Formiga et al. find that cadaverine modifies the energy metabolism and shapes macrophage pro- or anti-inflammatory polarization depending on context and concentration. The authors find that cadaverine enhances monocyte energy metabolism in an ATP assay screen, and they validate this in human primary cells. Through RNA sequencing of sorted human CD14+ monocytes, targeted metabolomics, pharmacological inhibition of amino acid transporters and using cells deficient in oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) function, they show that cadaverine is transported by l-lysine carriers and modulates the mitochondrial membrane potential, which supports the metabolic flux toward OXPHOS. By doing proteomics and stimulating with lipopolysaccharide, they discover that the mechanisms behind those immunometabolic responses differ between basal and inflammatory conditions. Cadaverine administration in antibiotic-treated mice prevented metabolic disruptions but had no influence in microbiota-intact mice. They see Enterobacteriaceae imbalance in a colitis mouse model and in patients with inflammatory bowel disease, concluding that gut Enterobacteriaceae regulates cadaverine implication in inflammatory bowel disease. Mice treatment with colistin or NRF2 inhibitor shows that cadaverine regulates monocyte and/or macrophage function through metabolic reprogramming, depending on concentration, with high levels exacerbating inflammation and its anti-inflammatory properties being dependent on NRF2.

Original reference: Cell Host Microbe https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chom.2025.09.009 (2025)
